awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Judicial Legitimacy in Comparative Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Political incumbents around the world commonly introduce legislation to undermine or politicize the judicial branch of government, such as "packing" the court's membership, or reducing the court's ability to decide certain cases. Political scientists have long thought that citizens will punish incumbents who advance these "court curbing" proposals in the next election. Nevertheless, these attacks continue. This project seeks to understand the conditions under which voters are both willing and able punish incumbent politicians who undermine high courts, as well as the circumstances under which politicians may actually benefit from these interbranch assaults. The researchers will explain variation in citizens' support for judicial institutions in 12 countries as a function of their satisfaction with the court's policymaking, their democratic values, their support for incumbents, and the political context in which they live. Understanding the foundations and consequences of judicial legitimacy around the globe is essential for building and maintaining the rule of law worldwide.

The key intellectual contribution of this study is the use of an original survey experiment, fielded in 12 countries around the world, to probe the electoral costs and benefits of interbranch attacks for incumbent politicians. The experiment relies on a novel dependent variable, a citizen's willingness to withdraw support from an incumbent who openly seeks to undermine courts, to examine directly a behavioral manifestation of legitimacy theory. Because public support is a theoretical antecedent to a willingness to punish incumbents for court curbing proposals, the surveys will contain validated measures of individuals' willingness to ascribe institutional legitimacy to judicial institutions, the first fielding of these items on cross-national surveys in over a quarter-century. With these original data, the researchers will test differences in the foundations of institutional legitimacy across countries. The theoretical framework for this research emphasizes the role of democratic values, a concept that is often referenced in existing studies of judicial legitimacy but has not been tested in a systematic fashion. This project therefore advances beyond earlier attempts to understand judicial legitimacy in its theoretical focus, experimental design, and the breadth of data incorporated into the study. Findings from this research will inform political scientists, legal scholars, policymakers and academics to better understand the public foundations of judicial independence and the rule of law, two foundational concepts in governance across continents.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past century, countries around the globe have created constitutional courts whose empowerment and independence promised commitments to property rights, expanded opportunity for human rights entrenchment and protection, and an entrenchment of the rule of law. But, as these courts have been granted (and learned to wield) the authority to hold incumbent governments into account, they have often found themselves squarely in the crosshairs of the institutions whose actions they were empowered to constrain. In some instances, courts have become a focal point of incumbent cooptation, as power-hungry executives viewed newly empowered judicial authorities as opportunities to entrench  their preferred policies. Elsewhere, overt attacks on courts seek to intimidate judges, to curtail judicial power, and to limit the constraint independent courts can impose. A pressing question is no longer how to promote judicial independence, but instead how to protect integrity of independent judiciaries and ensure that the benefits of judicial independence can be realized.

Public support for constitutional courts is one possible safeguard. Citizens' commitment to judicial institutions may shield courts from attacks on their independence and institutional integrity. Prominent models of judicial independence have long suggested that democratically-elected legislatures or executives who attack courts do so at their own peril, provided that courts are broadly supported by the public. This is because, so the story has gone, the public will retaliate in response to politicians' attacks on the judiciary. The goal of our project was to put this theory to the test, advancing beyond earlier attempts in its theoretical focus, research design, and breadth of empirical inquiry. 

We developed a theoretical framework that aims to understand when, where, and how publics are likely to retaliate against incumbents who seek to weaken the judiciary. We tested this theory using survey experiments fielded on nationally representative samples of eight Latin American countries and the United States and a new observational dataset of attacks on judicial independence throughout the region over the last 30 years. In our book manuscript and a series of peer-reviewed articles, we demonstrate that the public’s willingness to retaliate against incumbents’ attacks’ on courts is surprisingly limited. Further, we show that findings about the American public’s support for the U.S. Supreme Court do not necessarily translate to other high courts, especially those that are newer or less consolidated democracies.

The implication of our findings is that institutional integrity of courts does not rank highly on many voters’ considerations in comparison to economic issues and the social issues they care deeply about. In order to protect judicial independence, a support structure—including nongovernmental organizations like interest groups, a free and independent media, and a well-respected legal academy and bar association—may be necessary to help warn the public of attacks on judicial independence and to translate the consequences of these attacks to a public who may often not appreciate their severity or consequences. More broadly, the book will inform future theorizing about the costs of eroding institutions and what sorts of conditions are likely to facilitate the public's ability to stop threats to institutional integrity.

Over the life of the grant, we have supported and engaged students at both the undergraduate and graduate level. At both Penn State and Florida State, the co-PIs have worked closely with graduate and undergraduate research assistants, who have assisted in collecting relevant secondary data, running and replicating analyses and visualizations of data provided for by the grant, developing teaching materials, technical briefs and academic articles, and using the data for their own independent research. We have founded and sustained the “Courts in Context” workshop, which once a year convenes a diverse cross-section of scholars at all career stages to present and discuss research relating to public support for judicial institutions in the US and elsewhere. We have strived to integrate graduate students and early career scholars in these conferences, in both formal and informal capacities. Finally, we presented results major disciplinary conferences, at invited presentations at academic institutions, and various international conferences that bring together scholars and practitioners from a diverse set of disciplinary approaches.
